facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 480 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 480 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 4, 1964 of Madras High Court in Civil Revision Petition No. 1251 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated September 4, 1964 of the Madras High Court Civil Revision Petition No. 1251 of 1963.

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed petition for revision under section 115 of Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against an order passed by the High Court of Madras dismissing a petition for revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Sub-Collector Cheranmahadevi passed order permitting respondents to deposit arrears of rent due in respect of holding of which Kanda Devan was tenant.

anchor.surface_text: In the revision application the appellant had challenged the order of the Sub-Collector, Cheranmahadevi, by virtue of which the respondents were per- mitted to deposit the arrears of rent due in respect of a holding of which one Kanda Devan was a tenant.

facts.text: Order of Sub-Collector made under section 33A of Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid order was made under s. 3  3   a  of the Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955.

facts.text: Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955 originally to remain in force for three years but still in force by virtue of amending acts extending duration.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that this Act which was originally to, remain in force for a period of three years is still in force by virtue of the provisions of amending acts passed extending its duration from time to time.

facts.text: Kanda Devan was the cultivating tenant.

anchor.surface_text: In the revision application the appellant had challenged the order of the Sub-Collector, Cheranmahadevi, by virtue of which the respondents were per- mitted to deposit the arrears of rent due in respect of a holding of which one Kanda Devan was a tenant.

facts.text: Kanda Devan died some time before proceedings before Sub-Collector commenced.

anchor.surface_text: What happened was that Kanda Devan, who was the cultivating tenant, died some time before the proceedings before the Sub-Collector companymenced.

facts.text: Kanda Devan left behind heirs: widow Palaniachi Ammal and daughter Ramalakshmi Ammal.

anchor.surface_text: He left behind as his heirs his widow Palaniachi Ammal and his daughter Ramalakshmi Ammal.

facts.text: Respondent is the daughter's husband and holds power of attorney from her and Palaniachi Ammal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent before us is the daughters husband and holds a power of attorney both from her and Palaniachi Ammal.

facts.text: There was default in payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: There was default in payment of rent and so the respondent by virtue of the power of the attorney in his favour made an application

facts.text: Respondent made application in the year 1962 before Sub-Collector under section 33A for depositing rental arrears.

anchor.surface_text: There was default in payment of rent and so the respondent by virtue of the power of the attorney in his favour made an application in the year 1962 before the Sub-Collector under s. 3  3   a  of the Act for depositing the rental arrears.

facts.text: Appellant contested the application on ground that wife and daughter of Kanda Devan were not cultivating tenants as they were not personally cultivating the land.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who is the landlord companytested the application on the ground that neither the wife number the daughter of the deceased Kanda Devan was a cultivating tenant as defined in the Act because they were number personally cultivating the land

facts.text: Sub-Collector overruled the objection and directed respondent to deposit the rental arrears.

anchor.surface_text: and that, therefore, they were number entitled to the protection afforded by the Act. The Sub- Collector over-ruled the objection and, as already stated, directed the respondent to deposit the rental arrears.

facts.text: Palaniachi Ammal and Ramalakshmi Ammal are heirs of Kanda Devan who was tenant entitled to protection of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the respondent was rightly allowed to deposit the arrears. It is number disputed that Palaniachi Ammal and Ramalakshmi Ammal are the heirs of Kanda Devan, who, being a tenant, was entitled to the protection of the Act.

facts.text: After death of Kanda Devan, the land is being cultivated on behalf of Palaniachi Ammal and Ramalakshmi Ammal.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that after the death of Kanda Devan the land is being cultivated on behalf of these two women and that they are number personally cultivating them,

facts.text: Palaniachi Ammal and Ramalakshmi Ammal are not personally cultivating the land in the sense of contributing physical labour.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that after the death of Kanda Devan the land is being cultivated on behalf of these two women and that they are number personally cultivating them, in the sense that they are number companytributing physical labour for its cultivation.

facts.text: Respondent contends that it is not necessary for tenant to contribute physical labour to be entitled to benefit of the provision.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, companytended on behalf of the respondent that it is number necessary for a tenant to companytribute physical labour before he can be held entitled to the benefit of the provision.

facts.text: No finding by Sub-Collector as to nature of work done by respondent in connection with the land.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, numberfinding by the Sub-Collector as to the nature of work, if any, which the respondent is doing in companynection with the supervision of the land in question.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside orders of both courts below and remits matter to Sub-Collector for deciding whether respondent was putting in physical labour.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we think that in the interest of justice we should set aside the orders of both the companyrts below and remit the matter to the Sub-Collector for deciding as to whether the respondent was putting in physical labour in the cultivation of the field.

facts.text: Appellant is the landlord.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who is the landlord companytested the application

facts.text: Heirs continue in possession of the land after determination of tenancy agreement as per definition.

anchor.surface_text: cultivating tenant in relation to any land means a person who carries on personal cultivation on such land and, under a tenancy agreement, express or implied, and includes- any such person who companytinues in possession of the land after the determination of the tenancy agreement and the heirs of such person,

facts.text: Respondent holds power of attorney in his favour.

anchor.surface_text: and so the respondent by virtue of the power of the attorney in his favour made an application

facts.text: No material on record before Supreme Court bearing on whether respondent contributes physical labour.

anchor.surface_text: If there is numbermaterial on record bearing on the point he should give opportunity to both the parties to make necessary pleadings and to adduce evidence.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated September 4, 1964 of the Madras High Court Civil Revision Petition No. 1251 of 1963.
dismissing a petition for revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
The aforesaid order was made under s. 3  3   a  of the Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 33A Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act 1955
concepts.unlisted_description: Permitting deposit of arrears of rent

anchor.surface_text: made an application in the year 1962 before the Sub-Collector under s. 3  3   a  of the Act for depositing the rental arrears.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 33A Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act 1955

anchor.surface_text: The expression cultivating tenant is defined thus in s. 2  a  of the Act cultivating tenant in relation to any land means a person who carries on personal cultivation on such land and, under a tenancy agreement, express or implied, and includes- any such person who continues in possession of the land after the determination of the tenancy agreement and the heirs of such person,

concepts.interpretation: Heirs of cultivating tenant entitled to protection if they satisfy conditions of personal cultivation

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: hat, therefore, they were number entitled to the protection afforded by the Act. The Sub- Collector over-ruled the objection and, as already stated, d

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2(a) Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act 1955

anchor.surface_text: By the Amending Act, Madras Act 14 of 1956, cl.  ee  was added to s. 2 which purports to define the meaning of the expression carry on personal cultivation. Clause  ee  reads thus a person is said to carry on personal cultivation on a land when he contributes his own physical labour or that of the members of his family in the cultivation of that land

concepts.interpretation: Requires contribution of own physical labour or that of family members; son-in-law qualifies as family member; supervision not equivalent to physical labour

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: illai.  1  In that case Balakrishna Iyer J., held that in order to qualify as a cultivating tenant within the meaning of the definition given in the A

issues.text: Whether the respondent was rightly allowed to deposit the arrears

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the respondent was rightly allowed to deposit the arrears.

issues.text: Whether neither the wife nor the daughter of the deceased Kanda Devan was a cultivating tenant as defined in the Act because they were not personally cultivating the land

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who is the landlord contested the application on the ground that neither the wife nor the daughter of the deceased Kanda Devan was a cultivating tenant as defined in the Act because they were not personally cultivating the land and that, therefore, they were not entitled to the protection afforded by the Act.

issues.text: Whether it is not necessary for a tenant to contribute physical labour before he can be held entitled to the benefit of the provision

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, contended on behalf of the respondent that it is not necessary for a tenant to contribute physical labour before he can be held entitled to the benefit of the provision.

issues.text: Whether a son-in-law can be regarded as a member of the family

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. C. Agarwal, appearing for the respondent, said that a son-in-law can be regarded as a member of the family because the word family is not to be construed in a narrow sense or meaning only a member of a Hindu joint family.

issues.text: Whether the respondent was putting in physical labour in the cultivation of the field

anchor.surface_text: remit the matter to the Sub-Collector for deciding as to whether the respondent was putting in physical labour in the cultivation of the field.

arguments.claim: A son-in-law can be regarded as a member of the family because the word family is not to be construed in a narrow sense or meaning only a member of a Hindu joint family.

arguments.court_reasoning: Act applies to all tenants irrespective of personal laws; dictionary defines family as group related by blood or marriage, so son-in-law member of wife's family.

arguments.claim: Even if son-in-law is family member, the respondent is not contributing any physical labour but is only doing some kind of supervision, and supervision is not tantamount to physical labour per Abubucker Lebbai.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the appellants, however, contends that even so the respondent is not contributing any physical labour but is only doing some kind of supervision. He further points out that according to the decision in Abubucker Lebbais case the work

arguments.claim: Physical labour or that of family members is required for personal cultivation; supervision does not qualify as physical labour.

No. 426 of 1953 Before a person can be a cultivating tenant, he or members of his family must contribute his or their own physical labour. I do not consider that the supervision

arguments.claim: Matter should be remitted to Sub-Collector to decide whether respondent was putting in physical labour, allowing pleadings and evidence if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, no finding by the Sub-Collector as to the nature of work, if any, which the respondent is doing in connection with the supervision of the land in question. In the absence of such a finding and in the absence of any relevant material before us we cannot deal with this argument. ... remit the matter to the Sub-Collector for deciding as to whether the respondent was putting in physical labour in the cultivation of the field. If there is no material on record bearing on the point he should give opportunity to both the parties to make necessary pleadings and to adduce evidence.

holdings.text: To carry on personal cultivation, a person must contribute his own physical labour or that of the members of his family; mere supervision does not constitute physical labour

anchor.surface_text: Construing a similar expression occurring in the Tanjore Tenants and Pannaiyal Protection Ordinance IV of 1952 Rajagopala Ayyangar J., observed in an unreported case W. P. No. 426 of 1953 Before a person can be a cultivating tenant, he or members of his family must contribute his or their own physical labour. I do not consider that the supervision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts view of Rajagopala Ayyangar J. that physical labour required and supervision insufficient; agrees with Rajamannar C.J. in Abubucker Lebbai rejecting broader view in Kunchitapatham Pillai as too wide

holdings.text: A son-in-law can be regarded as a member of his wife's family for the purposes of clause (ee) of section 2

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. C. Agarwal, appearing for the respondent, said that a son-in-law can be regarded as a member of the family because the word family is not to be construed in a narrow sense or meaning only a member of a Hindu joint family. He is quite right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Word 'family' not limited to Hindu joint family; Act applies irrespective of personal laws; dictionary defines family to include those related by marriage

holdings.text: Before heirs can benefit from the definition of cultivating tenant, they must establish that a family member is contributing physical labour to cultivation

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, said that though the heirs of Kanda Devan are not themselves exerting their physical labour the respondent who is the holder of a power of attorney from them is doing so and that, therefore, the heirs must be regarded as cultivating tenants. Reliance is placed in this connection on cl. ee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of clause (ee) to heirs under section 2(a); must satisfy personal cultivation requirement

holdings.text: In absence of finding on nature of respondent's work and relevant material, pleadings or evidence, orders set aside and matter remitted to Sub-Collector to decide if respondent putting in physical labour

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, no finding by the Sub-Collector as to the nature of work, if any, which the respondent is doing in connection with the supervision of the land in question. In the absence of such a finding and in the absence of any relevant material before us we cannot deal with this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No factual finding by Sub-Collector; no material before court; interest of justice requires remand with opportunity for pleadings and evidence

anchor.surface_text: Kunchitapatham Pillai v. Ranganatham Pillai.  1  In that case Balakrishna Iyer J., held that in order to qualify as a cultivating tenant within the meaning of the definition given in the Act it was number necessary that a person should put his own muscular effort into the soil.

precedents.cited_proposition: in order to qualify as a cultivating tenant within the meaning of the definition given in the Act it was not necessary that a person should put his own muscular effort into the soil

anchor.surface_text: W. P. No. 426 of 1953 Before a person can be a cultivating tenant, he or members of his family must companytribute his or their own physical labour. I do number companysider that the supervision of panniyals companyld be characterised as physical labour within the meaning of the definition clause.

precedents.cited_proposition: Before a person can be a cultivating tenant, he or members of his family must contribute his or their own physical labour. Supervision of panniyals could not be characterised as physical labour within the meaning of the definition clause

precedents.citation: Abubucker Lebbai v. Zamindar of Ettayapuram.  2

anchor.surface_text: Abubucker Lebbai v. Zamindar of Ettayapuram.  2  Rajamannar C.J., who delivered judgment of the Court, after companysidering the views of Balakrishna Iyer J., and Rajagopala Ayyangar J., and also certain English decisions agreed with the view of the latter, and in our view, rightly.

precedents.case_name: Abubucker Lebbai v. Zamindar of Ettayapuram
precedents.cited_proposition: view taken by Balakrishna Iyer J. was too wide; agreed with view of Rajagopala Ayyangar J.

anchor.surface_text: Abubucker Lebbais case 1  the work of supervision is number tantamount to physical labour. There is, however, numberfinding by the Sub-Collector as to the nature of work, if any, which the respondent is doing in companynection with the supervision of the land in question.

precedents.case_name: Abubucker Lebbai v. Zamindar of Ettayapuram
precedents.cited_proposition: the work of supervision is not tantamount to physical labour
